definitions.definition: Repeated exposure to one or more antigens such that an immune response is elevated and maintained above the natural unexposed state.
an elevated immune response in an egg-producing animal that has been hyperimmunized
a whole egg (table, hyperimmunized or otherwise)
a whole egg or any product or fraction obtained from a whole egg
an egg obtained from an egg-producing animal that is not maintained in a hyperimmunized state, i.e. an animal that has not been hyperimmunized
a control egg or an egg product obtained from a control egg
a whole egg obtained from an egg-producing animal maintained in a hyperimmune state, i.e. an egg-producing animal that has been hyperimmunized
a hyperimmunized egg or any product obtained from a hyperimmunized egg
a hyperimmunized egg product that is at least partially purified such that the concentration of antibodies in the concentrate is greater than the concentration of antibodies in a hyperimmunized egg
a whole egg that has been dried, for example, spray-dried
any oviparous animal, including any animal that lays an egg, such as avians, fish and reptiles
an animal that is a member of the class Aves, including but not limited to chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks, pheasants, quail, pigeons and ostriches
levels in excess of those found in eggs of egg-producing animals that are not hyperimmunized
any method of providing a subject with a substance, including orally, intranasally, parenterally (intravenously, intramuscularly, or subcutaneously), rectally, topically or intraocularly.

a substance that is able to induce a humoral antibody and/or cell-mediated immune response rather than immunological tolerance; signifies the ability to stimulate an immune response as well as react with the products of it, e.g. an antibody.

a protein that includes at least one complementarity determining region that binds to a specific target antigen; for example, an antibody can include a heavy chain variable region and a light chain variable region, or include two heavy chain variable regions and two light chain variable regions; in a particular embodiment, the antibody is a polyclonal antibody.
a population of antibody molecules that are capable of immunoreacting with different epitopes on a particular antigen; in a particular embodiment, the antibody is an IgY antibody.
the liver manifestations of alcohol overconsumption, including fatty liver (steatosis), alcoholic hepatitis, and chronic hepatitis with liver fibrosis or cirrhosis.

diseases and disorders related to alcohol consumption and include, but are not limited to, alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with delusions, alcohol abuse, excessive drinking, heavy drinking, problem drinking, alcohol intoxication, alcohol withdrawal, alcohol intoxication delirium, alcohol withdrawal delirium, alcohol-induced persisting dementia, alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder, alcohol dependence, alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with hallucinations, alcohol-induced mood disorder, alcohol-induced or associated bipolar disorder, alcohol-induced or associated post-traumatic stress disorder, alcohol-induced anxiety disorder.
A subject who meets DSM TY criteria for alcohol abuse (“repeated use despite recurrent adverse consequences”) but is not dependent on alcohol.

Men who drink more than 21 standard drinks per week and women who consume more than 14 standard drinks per week. One standard drink is 0.5 ounces (15 ml) of absolute alcohol, equivalent to 10 ounces (300 ml) of beer, 4 ounces (120 ml) of wine, or 1 ounce (30 ml) of 100-proof liquor. These individuals are not dependent on alcohol but may or may not meet DSM TV criteria for alcohol abuse.

Men who drink more than 14 standard drinks per week and women who consume more than 7 standard drinks per week. These individuals are not dependent on alcohol but may or may not meet DSM TV criteria for alcohol abuse.

The amount of hyperimmunized egg product which when administered to a subject is sufficient to prevent or treat a disorder, e.g., alcoholic liver disease (ALD) or graft-vs-host disease (GVHD). The effective amount can vary depending, for example, on the age, weight, and/or health of the subject to be treated.

A biological compound (e.g., a protein) that is purified or partially purified from the cell in which it was produced. For example, an isolated Enterococcus faecalis cytolysin toxin is purified or partially purified from the Enterococcus faecalis cell in which it was produced. In some embodiments, the isolated Enterococcus faecalis cytolysin toxin is a recombinant Enterococcus faecalis cytolysin toxin, e.g., an Enterococcus faecalis cytolysin toxin that is produced in a cell other than an Enterococcus faecalis cell.
a spectrum of liver disorders including fatty liver (steatosis), alcoholic hepatitis, and chronic hepatitis with liver fibrosis or cirrhosis
the accumulation of fatty acids in liver cells
the development of large fatty globules throughout the liver
the enzyme that metabolizes ethanol into acetaldehyde
the enzyme that converts acetaldehyde into acetic acid
the inflammation of hepatocytes that predisposes the liver to fibrosis

a late stage of serious liver disease marked by inflammation (swelling), fibrosis (cellular hardening) and damaged membranes preventing detoxification of chemicals in the body, ending in scarring and necrosis (cell death)
the most severe form of alcohol-related liver disease
a bacterium present in the human microbiome that can expand in abundance and produce the toxin cytolysin in patients with alcoholic liver disease
a toxin produced by Enterococcus faecalis that contributes to increased severity and mortality in alcoholic hepatitis
a virus that targets and lyses bacteria, such as cytolysin-positive Enterococcus faecalis
mice colonized with human bacteria from feces of alcoholic hepatitis patients, used to model ethanol-induced liver disease
a major complication after transplantation of solid organs and stem cells, in which donor immune cells attack the recipient’s body cells
the form of graft-versus-host disease observed within the first 100 days post-transplant
the form of graft-versus-host disease that occurs after 100 days post-transplant
the donated tissue transplanted into a recipient
the recipient of a transplant
acute graft-versus-host disease affecting the skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract and occurring when donor T cells recognize recipient tissue as foreign and trigger tissue inflammation and injury
strains of Enterococcus faecalis that are cytolysin-positive, correlating with the severity of alcoholic liver disease and patient mortality in alcoholic hepatitis
the gene encoding the large subunit oligopeptide component of the functional cytolysin toxin in Enterococcus faecalis
the gene encoding the small subunit oligopeptide component of the functional cytolysin toxin in Enterococcus faecalis

Complex polycyclic antimicrobial peptides which are ribosomally synthesized by Gram-positive bacteria and are characterized by the presence of lanthionine and methyllanthionine bridges between dehydrated serine and threonine residues and cysteine thiols.
Graft-versus-host disease that results from allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation.

An enterococcal species in the gut that is an opportunistic pathogen and frequently causes life-threatening bloodstream infections in patients who have undergone allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation.
A dietary sugar that drives enterococcal growth in a mouse model of graft-versus-host disease.
an egg which comes from an avian which has been immunized with, for example, a specific antigen or mixture of antigens
An immunization regimen consisting of an initial immunization followed by one or two booster immunizations at 30 day intervals.
The class of animals commonly known as birds, including domesticated fowl such as chickens, turkeys, ducks, and geese.
enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays
The concentration of specific antibodies in a sample, as determined by ELISA.
Total chicken immunoglobulin Y extracted from eggs.
A reagent used to remove lipids from egg in preparation for IgY purification.
Egg powder produced by spray drying and reconstituted in sterile PBS for analysis.
Phosphate buffered saline, a sterile buffer used for reconstituting egg powder samples.
A flat-bottom microtiter plate with 96 wells used as the substrate for ELISA assays.
Biodegradable and nonantigenic materials used to encapsulate antibodies and other proteins; includes albumin, PLGA, globulin, natural and synthetic polymers, and thermoplastic polymers.
Agents used to crosslink the encapsulating material; includes glutaraldehyde.
A particle, typically spherical, with a diameter of less than 10 microns, for example from about 0.1 to about 10 microns.
a particle with a diameter of less than 1000 nm, optionally ranging from about 1 to about 1000 nm, including ranges such as about 100 to about 1000 nm or about 10 to about 100 nm

a process for encapsulating microparticles or nanoparticles using methods such as multi-walled microencapsulation, hot melt encapsulation, phase separation encapsulation, spontaneous emulsion, solvent evaporation microencapsulation, solvent removal microencapsulation, and coacervation
an immunoglobulin Y (IgY) antibody specific for a disclosed antigen, which can be purified and concentrated from egg products
quantitative PCR
Amount that is immunologically effective in treating or preventing alcoholic liver disease or GVHD.
a pharmaceutical formulation comprising a specified percentage (0.01% to 99% w/w) of hyperimmunized egg product.
immunoglobulin Y antibodies derived from egg yolk of hyperimmunized hens, specific to target antigens.
IgY antibodies specifically targeting Enterococcus faecalis bacteria.
IgY antibodies specifically targeting the cytolysin toxin produced by Enterococcus faecalis.
a toxin produced by Enterococcus faecalis with cytolytic activity.
a mouse model colonized with bacteria from alcoholic hepatitis patient feces to simulate alcoholic liver disease in humans.
Antibodies that inhibit the growth of E. faecalis, as demonstrated by 75% inhibition of bacterial colony formation.
a test for liver damage
a statistical test for comparing means across groups
